Award.AwardTitle: U.S.-Nepal Planning Visit to Initiate Collaborative Research in Geography and Environmental Engineering with Faculty at the Tribhuvan University in Kathmandu, Nepal, November 2010.
Award.AbstractNarration:
OISE- 1068472
U.S.-Nepal Planning Visit to Initiate Collaborative Research in Geography and Environmental Engineering with Faculty at the Tribhuvan University in Kathmandu, Nepal, November 2010.
PI Mohan Dangi of California State University (CSU) will undertake a planning visit to the Tribhuvan University (TU) where he will meet with the Heads of the Institute of Science and Technology, the Central Department of Environmental Science, and the Central Department of Botany. He and the foreign collaborators will identify future research opportunities in waste management, biogas generation, and climate change issues affecting Nepal. He will also examine the laboratory facilities, field research sites, appropriate mentors and the logistics in preparation for submission of an International Research Experience for Students (IRES) proposal to the Office of International Science & Engineering.
Intellectual Merit- This project will examine the effectiveness of low-cost waste treatment techniques that could be feasible for Nepal and other developing countries where managing urban waste is a growing challenge for governments. Dangi has thoroughly documented the analysis of waste management in Kathmandu and the indications are that a participatory style of management that promotes local protocols and strengthens the capacity of the municipality with waste specific treatment options can sustain such practices. Dangi is an Assistant Professor of Environmental Systems and Policy in the Department of Geography at CSU and a recent PhD from Johns Hopkins University in Geography and Environmental Engineering. He has conducted extensive research on understanding the technical-social interface of managing waste. The counterparts at Tribhuvan University are a well-matched, cross-disciplinary team that includes an environmental scientist, a botanist, and economist.
Broader Impacts- There are several broader impacts expected to result from this planning visit. One is that the visit will lay the groundwork for initiating a lasting research partnership between a US and Nepalese university. Secondly, the results of the research undertaken as part of this partnership could serve as a model for improving waste management practices in developing countries. During the visit, the PI will also develop a framework for the submission of an IRES proposal to NSF that will provide unique opportunities in environmental engineering for US undergraduate and graduates to work on research projects mentored by Nepalese professors. Directly connected with this is the co-development with TU faculty of effective IRES research projects for the US students that are mutually beneficial.

POR.DRECONTENT:
U.S.-Nepal Planning Visit to Initiate Collaborative Research in Geography and Environmental Engineering with Faculty at the Tribhuvan University in Kathmandu, Nepal, November 2010. NSF Award #1068472.

Project Outcomes Report

To fulfill the objectives of this grant, PI Dangi of California State University (CSU), Fresno traveled to Tribhuvan University (TU), Kathmandu, Nepal on November 19, 2010. Dangi arrived in Kathmandu on November 21 and held preliminary discussions with Dean, Dr. Mukunda P. Gajurel of host country institution (Institute of Science and Technology (IOST) of TU) to prepare planning workshop. In the morning of November 22, Dangi visited the Central Departments of Botany, Chemistry, Environmental Science, and Microbiology at IOST. In each of these departments, Dangi observed classroom instructions, interacted with students, examined laboratories, and answered students’ queries about possible partnership with CSU, Fresno. In the afternoon, Dangi toured recycling facility maintained by Women Environment Preservation Committee (WEPCO) in collaboration with the experts from Biogas Support Partnership Nepal in Kupondole, Lalitpur that will be used as a field research site by TU and CSU, Fresno students. In the morning of November 23, final preparation for Planning Workshop was carried out and in the afternoon, Dangi met with administrators of TU (Vice Chancellor, Rector, and Registrar) to inform them about prospective partnership between the two institutions and seek their support.

The Planning Workshop was organized for November 24-25, 2010. In the morning of November 24, Nepalese Minister for Science and Technology, Honorable Mr. Indra P. Dhungel inaugurated the workshop that was attended by TU administrators, faculty, and students. The closed sessions of the workshop were conducted in the afternoon of November 24 and all day on November 25. Altogether, 48 participants attended the inaugural session of the workshop and there were 21 and 17 experts that took part in the closed sessions of the days 1 and 2 of the workshop, respectively. On November 26, key attendees from the workshop met with Dangi to outline findings of the workshop and on November 27 Dangi left Kathmandu and arrived in Fresno on November 28. Also, while in Kathmandu, Dangi gave two talks covering his research work in solid waste at Kathmandu University on November 23 and 26, 2010.     

The major outcomes of the workshop included development of future International Research Experiences for Students (IRES) grant proposal involving 18 U.S. students covering three topics: (1) examination of waste treatment options and analysis of hazardous waste in Kathmandu; (2) exploration of landfill siting criteria and engineering design for landfills and evaluation of alternative waste treatment methods in Tulsipur Municipality; and (3) investigation of people’s livelihood, biodiversity, and vulnerability to climate change impacts in the Kali Gandaki River basin of Annapurna Conservation Area (ACA). Upon return from Nepal, Dangi worked extensively with his Nepalese counterparts and an IRES proposal titled, IRES: U.S.-Nepal Collaborative Research in Urban Waste Treatment Techniques and Climate Change in Annapurna Conservation Area, Nepal, was submitted to the NSF on February 14, 2011. The proposal is currently being reviewed by the NSF and is in pending status. While the most of the stipulated objectives in the Planning Grant were fulfilled; the lasting partnership between TU and CSU, Fresno will be further enhanced by the IRES grant, if funded.
